# Run all the .R code and manually type the results into the LaTeX table below
```{r}
df <- tribble(
  ~`Confidence Distribution`, ~`Range Tested`, ~`Max Absolute Error (Relative Error)`,
  "Logit-Normal($\\mu$, $\\sigma \\mid \\mu \\gg \\sigma$)", "$-10 \\leq \\mu \\leq 10$, $0.1 \\leq \\sigma \\leq 2.7$", "0.01 (2\\%)",
  "Beta($\\alpha$, $\\beta$)", "$0.1 \\leq \\alpha, \\beta \\leq 5$", "0.005 (0.9\\%)",
  "Kumaraswamy($\\alpha$, $\\beta$)", "$0.1 \\leq \\alpha, \\beta \\leq 5$", "0.003 (0.3\\%)",
  "Logit-Normal($\\mu$, $\\sigma \\mid \\mu \\leq \\sigma$)", "$-5 \\leq \\mu \\leq 5$, $0.2 \\leq \\sigma \\leq 5$", "0.07 (12\\%)",
  "Uniform(min, max)", "$0.1 \\leq min < max \\leq 0.9$", "0.02 (8\\%)",
  "Mixture of Betas($p_1$, $\\alpha_1$, $\\beta_1$, $\\alpha_2$, $\\beta_2$)",
  "$0.2 < p_1 < 0.8$, $0.2 \\leq \\alpha_1, \\beta_1, \\alpha_2, \\beta_2 \\leq 10$", "0.04 (12\\%)"
)

df
```

```{r sim_res}
df |>
  kbl(booktabs = T, escape = F, caption = "Maximum absolute and relative error between simulated and analytic Bayes-optimal accuracies under non-Gaussian confidence distributions. For unimodal distributions (Logit-Normal with $\\mu \\gg \\sigma$, Beta, and Kumaraswamy), the Gaussian SDT approximation remains highly accurate, with errors below 1\\%.") |>
  kable_styling(latex_options = c("scale_down", "hold_position")) |>
  pack_rows("Unimodal", 1, 3) |>
  pack_rows("Non-unimodal", 4, 6)
```
